# K-nearest neighbor classifier

One of the **.darkorange[simplest classifications methods]**

--

<u>Algorithm:</u>

1. Choose a **.darkorange[distance measure]** (e.g. eucledian).

--

2. Choose a **.darkorange[number of neighbors]**, $K$ (*Note: Choose an odd number!*).

--

3. **.darkorange[Calculate the distance]** between data and other points.

--

4. Calculate the **.darkorange[rate for each class]** according to $K$: $Pr(Y=j|X=x_0) = \frac{1}{K}\sum_{i \in N_0}\mathrm{I}(y_i=j)$.

--

5. **.darkorange[Assign the majority class]**.

# Classification boundaries for K=1

```{r knn_map1, fig.height=5.2, fig.width=10, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}

x.test <- expand.grid(freq = seq(-2.6, 4.2, by = 0.1), 
                      spend = seq(-2, 2.9, by = 0.1))

library(class)
# K = 1

Example_knn <- knn(knnExample[,c(1,2)], x.test, 
                   knnExample[,3], k = 1, prob = TRUE)
prob <- attr(Example_knn, "prob")

df1 <- mutate(x.test, prob = prob, class = 0,  
              prob_cls = ifelse(Example_knn == class, 1, 0))

df2 <- mutate(x.test, prob = prob, class = 1,  
              prob_cls = ifelse(Example_knn == class, 1, 0))
bigdf <- bind_rows(df1, df2)

ggplot(bigdf) + 
  geom_point(aes(x = freq, y = spend, col = class), 
             data = mutate(x.test, class = Example_knn), size = 0.5) +
  geom_point(aes(x = freq, y = spend, col = as.factor(class)), 
             size = 3, shape = 1, data = knnExample, stroke = 1) + 
  geom_contour(aes(x = freq, y = spend, z = prob_cls, group = as.factor(class), 
                   color = as.factor(class)), size = 1, bins = 1, data = bigdf) + 
  theme_bw() +
    scale_color_manual(values=c(alpha("#E16462",1), alpha("#F89441",1)),labels = c("Window Shoppers","High Rollers"), name = "Types") +
  theme_bw() +
    theme_ipsum_fsc() + #plain 
  xlab("Frequency") + ylab("Spending ($)")+
  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
```

```{r, echo=TRUE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
d <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week11/1_KNN/data/purchases_type.csv")
```

# How accurate is this?

.pull-left[
- For **.darkorange[classification]** problems, we care about *false positive* and *false negative*.
  
  - Sometimes you will care more about being wrong on one side than the other.

]

.pull-right[
```{r}
pred.type <- knn %>% predict(test.data)

test.data <- test.data %>% mutate(prediction = pred.type)


test.data %>% select(type, prediction) %>% table

test.data %>% select(type, prediction) %>% table %>% proportions(., margin = 1) %>%
  round(., 3)

```
]

# K-Nearest Neighbors Regression

- We can also use KNN for **.darkorange[continuous outcomes]**

--

- **.darkorange[Similar]** to the KNN classifier, but now we will take the *average of the K-neighbors* for prediction:

$$\hat{f}(x_0) = \frac{1}{K}\sum_{i \in N_0}y_i$$

---
# KNN Regression in R?

.pull-left[
```{r, echo=TRUE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
library(caret)

d <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week11/1_KNN/data/purchases_type.csv")

set.seed(100)

n <- nrow(d)

train.row <- sample(1:n, 0.8*n)

test.data <- d %>% slice(-train.row)
train.data <- d %>% slice(train.row)

knnr <- train(
  spend ~. - type, data = train.data, #<<
  method = "knn",
  trControl = trainControl("cv", number = 10),
  preProcess = c("center","scale"),
  tuneLength = 50
  )
```
]
